# Ingredient Reactions Here are the ingredient creation reactions that any chef should be able to learn and use.
#Essential Ingredients
Though kitchens start out well-stocked with a variety of reagent ingredients already, it may not be clear how those reagents turn into solid ingredients you can cook with.
For any normal, Nanotrasen-approved kitchen, these are the most commonly used ingredients that a chef will likely need to make.
##Dough
Regular dough can be made with the following reagents:
-15u Flour -10u Water
If you replace the flour with cornmeal, see what happens to the end dough!
For the station's fiber-eating personnel, cotton dough can be made with the following reagents:
-10u Fiber -5u Flour -10u Water
All of these doughs can be cut and rolled, not necessarily in that order.
##Meat
You can make synthetic meat with: -25u Fat -5u Nutriment -10u Blood -10u Carbon
##Plastic
You can make plastic by heating the following reagents to 374K:
-5u Oil -3u Ash -2u Sulfuric Acid
##Crystals
You can create synthetic crystals for decoration by mixing and heating to 374k:
-15u Sugar -15u Water -5u Ethanol
##Gunpowder
You can create gunpowder, a component used in improvised explosives, by mixing: -6u Potassium -2u Sulfur -2u Charcoal
##Solidification
You can solidify reagents such as silver and gold into bars by using: -10u Metal (silver or gold) -5u Frost Oil
